text:
This century is going
to be the century

of emerging technologies
in the life sciences field.

We're now at a period of our
understanding of the human body

that we can begin to seriously
think not about treatments,
but about cures.

But I don't think that an
individual scientist really

knows exactly how to take
the basic science discovery

and make that a drug that we
can actually bring to market.

So the idea here is
let's collaborate

with the best and the
brightest scientists.

Let's bring people to
Harvard Business School,

give them an MBA, but also
give them an amazing science

education, which allows them
to lead the next generation
of bio-pharma companies.

We're excited to launch this
new MS/MBA program, because it

fills the need of
people who'd like

to make a difference
in the world

by developing new drugs
and new medicines.

They already know enough
science to see the promise,

but what they're missing
is a business sense of how
to commercialize science.

My guess is in a
decade, you will

be hard-pressed to get a
position in a biotech or pharma

company without having had
an experience like this.

The core of the curriculum
is an understanding

of how to take opportunities
to invest and evaluate

them scientifically,
medically, and ethically.

Students in this
program will have access

to HBS faculty members
and faculty members

from the Faculty of
Arts and Sciences

in Harvard Medical School
present in the classroom
at the same time.

We're delighted to collaborate
between my department
and the Harvard Business School.

The business school
has a tradition

and a history of excellence in
training managers and leaders
in new areas.

But one also needs mastery
of the basic science.

And what better
place to learn that

from the Department of Stem
Cell and Regenerative Biology.

They've thought long and hard
to do science to heal humanity.

I can't imagine a better place
to have this kind of program
than in Boston.

Because it is, at the moment,
the biomedical capital
of the world.

There is no other
city in the world that

has the agglomeration
of industry, hospitals,

scientists, and
great universities

all sitting a mile and a
half apart from each other.

I'm excited about the
prospect that we're

going to attract really
ambitious people who

think that they can
completely change the way we
think about treating disease.

In other words, we want
to provide leadership

for the whole scientific
medical enterprise.

The people who
believe it is within

our scientific
and economic grasp

to reduce human
suffering in the world--

those are the people who
should definitely apply.
